DOC.HEAD: Frigid Weather Again Boosts Orange Juice, Heating Oil Futures
DOC.TEXT: Frigid weather forecasts continued to boost orange juice and heating oil futures prices Thursday as a record-shattering Canadian cold front moved southward and eastward. On other commodity markets, precious metals turned lower; livestock and meat futures advanced; and grains and soybeans were mixed. Prices of most contracts for future deliveries of frozen concentrated orange juice soared the permitted daily limit of 5 cents a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange. The limitless contract for January delivery rose 7.25 cents to $1.417 a pound. Weather Services Corp., a private forecasting firm in Bedford, Mass., rated the probability of a weekend freeze in the Florida citrus belt at 80 percent Thursday, up from 75 percent on Wednesday and 50 percent the day before. Peter Leavitt, executive vice president of Weather Services, said the coldest temperatures _ projected at 18 to 28 degrees _ would likely occur Sunday morning in the citrus country. The expected freeze would rival one that occurred on Christmas Day in 1983, severely damaging the Florida orange crop, and could well be colder, Leavitt said. ``You cannot really underestimate the magnitude of this cold air mass for this time of year,'' Leavitt said. ``This will go into the books, I'm sure, as an historic event.'' The enter of the cold front plowed out of the Northern Plains and into the Midwest on Thursday, dropping temperatures as low as 22 below zero in Sioux City, Iowa, and pushing mercury below the freezing mark nearly as far south as the Gulf of Mexico. In the populous Northeast, the area most closely watched by heating oil traders at this time of year, the encroaching cold front promised no relief from the sub-normal temperatures that are likely to make this December the coldest on record. ``Temperatures in the Northeast have averaged below normal every single day this month,'' Leavitt said. ``This is the 23rd straight day of below-normal temperatures.'' The cold has forced fuel oil dealers to delve into their reserves to meet the extraordinary demand and, on Thursday, drove heating oil futures prices up sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange for the fifth straight day and the 16th time in the last 17 trading sessions. The buying spilled over into the crude oil and gasoline pits, powering futures prices for those commodities up as well. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 31 cents to 36 cents higher with February at $21.52 a barrel; heating oil was .90 cent to 4.05 cents higher with January at 79.81 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.55 cent to 2.41 cents higher with January at 55.63 cents a gallon. Precious-metals futures prices sagged in quiet trading on New York's Commodity Exchange as players squared their books ahead of the long holiday weekend. Gold futures finished $1.70 to $2.30 lower with December at $411.90 a troy ounce; silver was 0.5 cent to 1 cent lower with December at $5.543 a troy ounce. Livestock and meat futures settled higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after a late rally linked to technical factors and to the cold weather in the Midwest, which has cut deeply into hog marketings. Live cattle futures finished .35 cent to .50 cent higher with February at 76.80 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .40 cent higher with January at 84.80 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent to .33 cent higher with February at 49.47 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were unchanged to .38 cent higher with February at 49.60 cents a pound. Soybean futures prices settled slightly higher in a quiet session on the Chicago Board of Trade while grain futures finished narrowly mixed.
